newsitem.title: UK: UK's Brown made no new comment on stg - Treasury.
newsitem.headline: UK's Brown made no new comment on stg - Treasury.

text.p: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown made no comment about the level of the pound on Thursday, a Treasury official said.

"The last time he did an interview was Tuesday," the official said. He said rumours Brown had conducted a radio interview and discussed the pound, circulating in the New York market, were completely wrong.

On Tuesday, Brown announced the Bank of England would have operational independence to set interest rates. In a statement to reporters, he also said monetary policy is directed towards achieving price stability.
"We want a stable and competitive pound over the medium-term, consistent with our objective of price stability," he said in his statement on Tuesday.
Earlier on Thursday, a Treasury official told Reuters: "There is no question of adopting a target for the exchange rate."

The pound has had a rocky session, sliding four pfennigs after Bridge news agency reported that a Labour Party source had said re-entry into Europe's exchange rate mechanism might be attractive for sterling if the central rate was 2.50 marks.
The report was quickly denied by the Treasury which said "there is no truth in it at all."
